WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. L. Hargrove, Mrs. G. Thiele
Address: Spring Valley, Sask.
Birthplace: Germany

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1903
Where did you set up housekeeping? Killaly, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Central Europe
For how many people did you prepare meals? From 2 to 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 40 mi.
How often could a visit be made to the store? About once a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tobacco, sugar, tea, coffee, prunes, dried apples, corn syrup, cornmeal, oatmeal, salt and pepper, cinnamon, raisins for Christmas

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...........................................
In what quantities did you buy it? ...........................................
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $1.60 per 100
How much did you use graham flour? ...........................................
Whole wheat flour? ...........................................
Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? 40 mi. That year? 1903
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Didn't know
What other grain products did you use? ...........................................
Cornmeal? ✓ Whole wheat? Farina? ✓ Other? ...........................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No, but many neighbors did.
How did you grind it? With the coffee mill. Some used grinding stones
1. PERSONAL HISTORY

What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1903

Where did you set up housekeeping? Holcomb, Saskatchewan

Have you lived there before that? No

For how many years have you lived there? 24

How far was it to your nearest store? About 10 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a month

What groceries did you usually buy in town? Groceries, flour, sugar, salt, pepper, condiments.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 50 lb.

What was the price for a 50 pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Lily Brand.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? Half.

At what price? About 30¢ or 35¢.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Rept cows. When they went dry, we did without.

Did you keep cows? Yes.

What was the price of butter? $2.00 per 15 lbs. of eggs? 6¢ per dozen.

Did you keep hens? No.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Cottage cheese.

What kind of cheese? Cottage cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork, home-raised and cured chickens.

How did you get fresh meat?

How often did you get fresh meat? When we butchered once a year.

How did you preserve meat? Salted.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Rabbits, prairie chickens, wild ducks.

For how long? Three or four years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Plenty, fish was eaten in winter and spring. Indians brought it from the nearby lake.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Whitefish, pickerel, pike.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - porridge, bread, coffee.

Dinner - soup, potatoes, bread, tea.
After the first year, there would be vegetables.
(Sometimes butter)

Supper - potato soup, potatoes and gravy, bread and tea.
or coffee.
(a) Earle soup from rabbit stock, bread, tea.
Sometimes Johnny cake.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Coffee Kuchen made with dried apples
and cheese was the principal treat.
Whatever meat was on hand, pork or chicken
constituted the piece de resistance.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1904, we had nothing but frozen potatoes
and syrup for a week. Borrowed enough
flour to thicken a kind of soup.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Also give the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - porridge, bread, coffee.

Dinner - baked potatoes, fried tea, vegetable.

Supper - potato soup, potato and gravy, hard roll.

Coffee Klatch made with dried apple.

Coffee Klatch was the principal treat.

Whatever meat was on hand; pork or chicken.

Whatever kind of pie or dessert.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Tennessee?

Give the name. List those present and give their ages or names.

19. Have you ever refused to almost starve? If so, when? Give details.

Locally grown foods? Give details.

In 1904, we had nothing but frozen potatoes and syrup for a week. Borrowed enough flour to thicken a kind of soup.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

As time went on and we got a little cash, we began to use more prepared foods, but on the farm, we still rely as much as possible on our home grown products.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I should have mentioned that as soon as we had gardens, the barrel of sourkraut was an important institution. Many tasty dishes could be made with sourkraut as a base.
21. When did you begin to rely on preserved foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home-preserved foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

At first we tried to get a little each.

As time went on and we got more food, but we figured to save more food, so we started to grow our own produce.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of growing vegetables and eating foods in other parts of pioneer life in northern Canada.

Include areas not mentioned above, quality, methods of preservation, grades, problems of storage, shortages and other details. Use both of these columns if needed.

I should have mentioned that as soon as we had gardens, the family would start to eat important nourishment. Many times neither could be made with anything else.

A tree.
